content.description: Move left of the anchor and climb a thin crack to its top. Continue up the steepening face to where the angle changes. Pull onto the slab and continue up to a fixed anchor on a headwall.
content.location: At the right end of the cliff, locate the open areas, bombardment zones for falling ice. Above and right of these is a beautiful wall with the unmistakable route Debaser (5.13b). Scramble up to the ledge beneath Debaser, then scramble 40' left to a fixed anchor below an off-vertical, black wall.

content.description:
This climb has white-grey rock that is difficult to read. Lots of stemming and devious movements on this one. 

  Go up the corner to its top, then traverse left to gain a tips crack. Up this to another right-facing corner. Up the corner to its top, then go up and left to a fixed anchor.
content.location:
There are a couple clearings near the right end of the cliff; with the black rock above, these are clearly bombardment zones for falling ice. About 30' above the base of the cliff is a ledge that spans the right end of the cliff. Approach by walking left along the base of the cliff until you can scramble up, then rightwards onto this ledge. Walk back right along the ledge until you come to a wide, tall chimney. The route begins 15' left of this chimney at a shallow right-facing corner. 

  Walking further right leads to the Lichen Boobies area.

content.description:
There's a bunch of great routes on this cliff, but this one is extra special. The first pitch is a nice, easy slab, and the top pitch is a corner and crack -- exposed and awesome -- and overhangs about 10'. 

  P1 5.7 G: Go up steps, through a notch, then a short slab to a blueberry ledge. Go straight up the slab above aiming for a short right-facing corner, above which is a comfortable ledge with a fixed anchor. 80' 

  P2 5.11a G: This is what you hiked here for. Step right from the ledge and go up a right-facing corner to a sloping stance. There's a couple deceptively difficult moves in this corner. From here it's a sprint to the top: go up an overhanging crack to the top. 80'
content.location:
Approximately centered in the cliff is a tall, nearly featureless slab that runs the full height of the cliff, known as the Treadway Face. It's difficult to locate this slab from the ground, as it's hidden above large roofs. Right of this slab is a left-rising gully-slope in a giant right-facing corner. Scramble up the gully in the giant corner until you can move right onto a narrow ledge with a pine tree. 

  This is the tallest section of rock.

content.description:
This good warmup ascends a naturally-clean, blunt arete.

 Climb the arete (and face to its left) to a ledge with a fixed anchor.
content.location: The route is located on the terrace that divides the right end of the cliff above the ice-fall clearings. On the terrace, locate a wide chimney (used as a locator for Rural Juror). Continue rightwards on the terrace to a large right-facing corner. Begin 25' right of this corner at a black arete.

content.description:
Another amazing pitch of climbing at this remote cliff. 

  Go up a slab to a short, orange wall. Up this, then wander up the slab to a roof below an overhanging, white corner. Tackle the roof (crux), then up the corner and through the roof system to an exposed belay.
content.location: On the ledge 25' right of North Country for Old Men.

content.description: This wide, south-facing cliff sits just north of Pharaoh Lake. The rock is a quartzy with good edges, but very few cracks. Beautiful location.
